clusters.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs
clusters.neutral_headline: Sweet perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs

items.title: Eau de courgette: rise in foodie perfumes may be linked to weight-loss drugs
items.standfirst: ‘Gourmand’ fragrances with notes of biscuit or cherries are also trending among young consumers onlineA rise in the number of sweet, food-scented perfumes on the market could be linked to an increase in the use of weight-loss medication, according to the market research firm Mintel.Food-inspired fragrances, with scent profiles that feature vanilla, coffee and caramel and referred to in the industry as “gourmand” perfumes, have surged in popularity in the past three years. Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading...

Launches of sugary-scented, dessert-themed fragrances increased by 24% last year alone, Mintel said. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths each year, says new study
clusters.neutral_headline: Oil and gas air pollution causes premature deaths in the US

items.title: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths each year, says new study
items.standfirst: Study analyzed health impacts of fossil fuels from exploration to end use, and found communities of color bear brunt of harmAir pollution from oil and gas causes more than 90,000 premature deaths and sickens hundreds of thousands of people across the US each year, a new study shows, with disproportionately high impacts on communities of color.More than 10,000 annual pre-term births are attributable to fine particulate matter from oil and gas, the authors found, also linking 216,000 annual childhood-onset asthma cases to the sector’s nitrogen dioxide emissions and 1,610 annual lifetime cancer cases to its hazardous air pollutants. Continue reading...
items.content: Study analyzed health impacts of fossil fuels from exploration to end use, and found communities of color bear brunt of harmAir pollution from oil and gas causes more than 90,000 premature deaths and sickens hundreds of thousands of people across the US each year, a new study shows, with disproportionately high impacts on communities of color.More than 10,000 annual pre-term births are attributable to fine particulate matter from oil and gas, the authors found, also linking 216,000 annual childhood-onset asthma cases to the sector’s nitrogen dioxide emissions and 1,610 annual lifetime cancer cases to its hazardous air pollutants. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Air pollution from oil and gas causes 90,000 premature US deaths annually.
Communities of color bear a disproportionate burden of harm.
Over 10,000 pre-term births are linked to oil and gas particulate matter.
216,000 childhood-onset asthma cases are linked to nitrogen dioxide emissions.
1,610 annual cancer cases are linked to hazardous air pollutants.

items.title: Wes Streeting’s row with pharma firms grows as they reject NHS drug pricing offer
items.standfirst: Drugmakers fail to meet health secretary’s latest offer, meaning ‘unsustainable’ rebate scheme will stay in placeA row between Wes Streeting and pharmaceutical companies has intensified after drugmakers rejected the health secretary’s latest offer on NHS drug pricing.The two sides failed to reach agreement by a midday deadline on Friday, meaning the mechanism under which the health service claws back some of the money it pays for medicines will continue at a rate the industry said was “unsustainable” and could ultimately disadvantage patients. Continue reading...
items.content: Drugmakers fail to meet health secretary’s latest offer, meaning ‘unsustainable’ rebate scheme will stay in placeA row between Wes Streeting and pharmaceutical companies has intensified after drugmakers rejected the health secretary’s latest offer on NHS drug pricing.The two sides failed to reach agreement by a midday deadline on Friday, meaning the mechanism under which the health service claws back some of the money it pays for medicines will continue at a rate the industry said was “unsustainable” and could ultimately disadvantage patients. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Drugmakers rejected the health secretary's latest offer on NHS drug pricing.
The current rebate scheme will remain in place, according to the article.
The industry claims the rebate scheme is "unsustainable" for them.
The industry suggests the scheme could disadvantage patients.
The two sides failed to reach an agreement by a Friday midday deadline.

clusters.title: As measles gains ground in US, Texas offers lessons from its outbreak
clusters.neutral_headline: Measles outbreak in Texas offers lessons

items.title: As measles gains ground in US, Texas offers lessons from its outbreak
items.standfirst: Vaccine-hesitant communities might benefit from free treatment centers and smaller vaccination clinicsThe measles outbreak in Texas has officially ended, but as cases continue to be detected in other parts of the US state health experts are warning of the need to prepare for outbreaks in undervaccinated communities, especially as anti-vaccine beliefs are becoming more prominent during the Trump administration.So far this year, 1,356 confirmed measles cases, largely from 32 outbreaks, have been reported across the US – compared with last year’s entire total of 285 cases and 16 outbreaks. While the Texas outbreak initially drove the case counts, other US outbreaks are now contributing in increasing numbers. Continue reading...
items.content: Vaccine-hesitant communities might benefit from free treatment centers and smaller vaccination clinicsThe measles outbreak in Texas has officially ended, but as cases continue to be detected in other parts of the US state health experts are warning of the need to prepare for outbreaks in undervaccinated communities, especially as anti-vaccine beliefs are becoming more prominent during the Trump administration.So far this year, 1,356 confirmed measles cases, largely from 32 outbreaks, have been reported across the US – compared with last year’s entire total of 285 cases and 16 outbreaks. While the Texas outbreak initially drove the case counts, other US outbreaks are now contributing in increasing numbers. Continue reading...

ai_summary: 1,356 confirmed measles cases have been reported across the US this year.

clusters.title: California resident tests positive for the plague after camping, officials say

items.title: California resident tests positive for the plague after camping, officials say
items.standfirst: South Lake Tahoe resident was probably bitten by infected flea while camping in the area, local health authorities sayA resident of South Lake Tahoe in California has tested positive for the plague, local authorities announced this week.A statement released on Tuesday by health officials in El Dorado county said they were notified of the situation by the California department of public health (CDPH). The statement said the individual is now recovering at home and is under the care of a medical professional. Continue reading...

The statement said the individual is now recovering at home and is under the care of a medical professional. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Obesity has a serious impact on health – it shortened my mum’s life | Letter
clusters.neutral_headline: Obesity has a serious impact on health

items.title: Obesity has a serious impact on health – it shortened my mum’s life | Letter
items.standfirst: Blaming the patriarchy, fatphobia or big pharma for weight issues doesn’t reduce the risks, says Frances KnightWith reference to the letters on Rose Stokes’ article (I thought we’d entered the age of body positivity. Then came ‘shrinking girl summer’ – is everyone getting smaller except me?, 10 August), I would like to add a personal view. My lovely mom was overweight all of her adult life – between 17 stone and 18 stone. She could never run around and play with us children. In her 40s she developed diabetes and high blood pressure. Many DVTs and pulmonary embolisms followed. She died of a coronary aged 62.We should all live without fear of stigma and ridicule. This doesn’t mean that we should make choices that shorten our lives or encourage others to do so. Being overweight brings health risks. Blaming the patriarchy, fatphobia or big pharma doesn’t reduce those risks. Continue reading...
items.content: Blaming the patriarchy, fatphobia or big pharma for weight issues doesn’t reduce the risks, says Frances KnightWith reference to the letters on Rose Stokes’ article (I thought we’d entered the age of body positivity. Then came ‘shrinking girl summer’ – is everyone getting smaller except me?, 10 August), I would like to add a personal view. My lovely mom was overweight all of her adult life – between 17 stone and 18 stone. She could never run around and play with us children. In her 40s she developed diabetes and high blood pressure. Many DVTs and pulmonary embolisms followed. She died of a coronary aged 62.We should all live without fear of stigma and ridicule. This doesn’t mean that we should make choices that shorten our lives or encourage others to do so. Being overweight brings health risks. Blaming the patriarchy, fatphobia or big pharma doesn’t reduce those risks. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author's mother was overweight and died at age 62.
The author's mother developed diabetes and high blood pressure.
The author's mother had multiple DVTs and pulmonary embolisms.
The author believes being overweight brings health risks.
The author's mother's life was shortened by obesity.

clusters.title: UK firms misleading parents with milk teeth autism treatment claims, report finds
clusters.neutral_headline: UK firms misleading parents with autism treatment claims

items.title: UK firms misleading parents with milk teeth autism treatment claims, report finds
items.standfirst: Charity says it is ‘outrageous’ tooth stem cell procedures are being advertised with claims about ‘treating’ autismCompanies are making thousands of pounds by misleading parents with claims that collecting stem cells from their children’s teeth can be a treatment for diabetes and autism, an investigation has found.Tooth stem cell banking, also known as dental pulp cell banking, involves parents collecting and sending lost milk teeth to a laboratory where stem cells are harvested from the dental pulp. Firms that advertise tooth banking services claim these stem cells can be used in treatments for conditions such as diabetes as well as for autism. Continue reading...
items.content: Charity says it is ‘outrageous’ tooth stem cell procedures are being advertised with claims about ‘treating’ autismCompanies are making thousands of pounds by misleading parents with claims that collecting stem cells from their children’s teeth can be a treatment for diabetes and autism, an investigation has found.Tooth stem cell banking, also known as dental pulp cell banking, involves parents collecting and sending lost milk teeth to a laboratory where stem cells are harvested from the dental pulp. Firms that advertise tooth banking services claim these stem cells can be used in treatments for conditions such as diabetes as well as for autism. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Companies are misleading parents with false claims.
Firms claim stem cells from teeth can treat autism.
Tooth stem cell banking involves collecting milk teeth.
The investigation found misleading advertising practices.
Firms are making money by misleading parents.

clusters.title: Why 'baby brain' isn't what we think – video
clusters.neutral_headline: Pregnancy Rewires Brains, Study Reveals, Not Weakening It

items.title: Why 'baby brain' isn't what we think – video
items.standfirst: ‘Baby brain’ is often referenced jokingly and dismissively when discussing pregnancy and forgetfulness. But a new brain scan study reveals something more profound: pregnancy does not weaken the brain, it rewires it. Neelam Tailor explores what this means for neuroscience and caregiving, and how little we still understand about women’s health Continue reading...

But a new brain scan study reveals something more profound: pregnancy does not weaken the brain, it rewires it. Neelam Tailor explores what this means for neuroscience and caregiving, and how little we still understand about women’s health Continue reading...

clusters.title: ‘Russia is targeting us deliberately’: how attacks on maternity hospitals fuelled a birth-rate crisis in Ukraine
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘Russia is targeting us deliberately’: how attacks on maternity hospitals fuelled a birth-rate crisis in Ukraine

items.title: ‘Russia is targeting us deliberately’: how attacks on maternity hospitals fuelled a birth-rate crisis in Ukraine
items.standfirst: The Guardian has visited three frontline hospitals to hear from women who say they have been left fearful of childbirth after more than 80 attacks on maternity units since Russia’s full-scale invasionIt was one of the most horrifying targets of Russia’s war on Ukraine so far. Reports showed a pregnant woman on a stretcher, her face ashen with shock, legs smeared with blood and a hand holding her bump. Behind her, the bombed-out ruins of Mariupol’s maternity hospital. More than a dozen people, including women in labour, were injured in the attack in March 2022. The woman photographed, Iryna Kalinina, later died along with her unborn baby.In the three years since then, maternity care in Ukraine has remained under constant attack, with more than 2,000 strikes on medical facilities, including 81 affecting maternal care and delivery rooms. Just last month, Diana Koshyk, seven months pregnant, was killed when a missile struck a maternity hospital in the eastern Dnipropetrovsk region. Continue reading...
items.content: The Guardian has visited three frontline hospitals to hear from women who say they have been left fearful of childbirth after more than 80 attacks on maternity units since Russia’s full-scale invasionIt was one of the most horrifying targets of Russia’s war on Ukraine so far. Reports showed a pregnant woman on a stretcher, her face ashen with shock, legs smeared with blood and a hand holding her bump. Behind her, the bombed-out ruins of Mariupol’s maternity hospital. More than a dozen people, including women in labour, were injured in the attack in March 2022. The woman photographed, Iryna Kalinina, later died along with her unborn baby.In the three years since then, maternity care in Ukraine has remained under constant attack, with more than 2,000 strikes on medical facilities, including 81 affecting maternal care and delivery rooms. Just last month, Diana Koshyk, seven months pregnant, was killed when a missile struck a maternity hospital in the eastern Dnipropetrovsk region. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Guardian visited hospitals to hear from women fearful of childbirth.
Over 80 attacks on maternity units have occurred since the invasion.
A pregnant woman in Mariupol died after a hospital bombing in March 2022.
More than 2,000 strikes on medical facilities have occurred in Ukraine.
A pregnant woman was killed in a missile strike on a hospital last month.

clusters.title: Corporal punishment carries ‘multiple risks’ to children’s health, says WHO
clusters.neutral_headline: WHO: Corporal Punishment Poses Multiple Risks to Children's Health

items.title: Corporal punishment carries ‘multiple risks’ to children’s health, says WHO
items.standfirst: An estimated 1.2bn children are subject to this ‘harmful practice’ each year, affecting physical and mental wellbeing, report findsThe World Health Organization has declared corporal punishment a global public health concern that causes serious harm to children’s physical and mental wellbeing, and can lead to criminal behaviour.A new report found that across 49 low- and middle-income countries, children exposed to corporal punishment – defined as “any punishment in which physical force is used and intended to cause some degree of pain or discomfort, however light” – were 24% less likely to be developmentally on track than children who were not. Continue reading...
items.content: An estimated 1.2bn children are subject to this ‘harmful practice’ each year, affecting physical and mental wellbeing, report findsThe World Health Organization has declared corporal punishment a global public health concern that causes serious harm to children’s physical and mental wellbeing, and can lead to criminal behaviour.A new report found that across 49 low- and middle-income countries, children exposed to corporal punishment – defined as “any punishment in which physical force is used and intended to cause some degree of pain or discomfort, however light” – were 24% less likely to be developmentally on track than children who were not. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The World Health Organization calls corporal punishment a global health concern.
Corporal punishment affects children's physical and mental well-being.
The practice can lead to criminal behavior in children.
An estimated 1.2 billion children are subjected to corporal punishment annually.
Children exposed to corporal punishment are less likely to develop on track.

clusters.title: ‘I dream about toilets, I admit it’: the man on a mission to improve Britain’s loos
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Works to Improve Public Toilets in Britain

items.title: ‘I dream about toilets, I admit it’: the man on a mission to improve Britain’s loos
items.standfirst: Poor accessibility, questionable hygiene, scattered needles and budget cuts … the UK is in the midst of a public toilet crisis. Thankfully, Raymond Martin is fighting backThe first thing Raymond Martin looks for in a toilet, he says, is cleanliness. Does the tissue paper on the floor mean this public lavatory has failed his inspection? “You have to understand that it’s a working toilet, it’s now mid-afternoon – a few bits of tissue on the floor is neither here nor there,” Martin says. “If there were cigarette packets, bottles on the floor – that I’d be worried about.” We’re in Knutsford, Cheshire, and Martin is on a toilet-inspection tour of the north and west of the UK. He’s just come from the Lake District and Blackpool. When we part ways in a couple of hours, he’ll head on to Wales to inspect the public conveniences of Pembrokeshire.Do people laugh when Martin, who is managing director of the British Toilet Association (BTA), tells them he does toilet inspections? They do, he says. “But then, immediately, they say, ‘I’ll tell you where I was and they had wonderful toilets …’.” Continue reading...
items.content: Poor accessibility, questionable hygiene, scattered needles and budget cuts … the UK is in the midst of a public toilet crisis. Thankfully, Raymond Martin is fighting backThe first thing Raymond Martin looks for in a toilet, he says, is cleanliness. Does the tissue paper on the floor mean this public lavatory has failed his inspection? “You have to understand that it’s a working toilet, it’s now mid-afternoon – a few bits of tissue on the floor is neither here nor there,” Martin says. “If there were cigarette packets, bottles on the floor – that I’d be worried about.” We’re in Knutsford, Cheshire, and Martin is on a toilet-inspection tour of the north and west of the UK. He’s just come from the Lake District and Blackpool. When we part ways in a couple of hours, he’ll head on to Wales to inspect the public conveniences of Pembrokeshire.Do people laugh when Martin, who is managing director of the British Toilet Association (BTA), tells them he does toilet inspections? They do, he says. “But then, immediately, they say, ‘I’ll tell you where I was and they had wonderful toilets …’.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Raymond Martin inspects public toilets across the United Kingdom.
Martin is the managing director of the British Toilet Association.
He prioritizes cleanliness when inspecting public restrooms.
The UK faces a public toilet crisis due to various issues.
Martin's work involves assessing accessibility and hygiene standards.
